title: What is Metabolic Reconstruction?
content: Metabolic reconstruction is the process of building a comprehensive, genome-scale model of an organism's metabolism by integrating genomic, biochemical, and physiological data. It results in a structured network of metabolic reactions that can be used for simulation and analysis.

title: Steps in Genome-Scale Metabolic Model (GEM) Reconstruction
content: The standard workflow includes: (1) draft reconstruction from annotated genomes using databases like KEGG or MetaCyc, (2) manual curation and gap-filling, (3) compartmentalization, (4) biomass reaction definition, and (5) model validation through experimental data.

title: Common Tools for Metabolic Reconstruction
content: Popular software tools include CarveMe, ModelSEED, Pathway Tools, RAVEN Toolbox, and COBRApy. These support automated draft generation, simulation (e.g., FBA), and refinement of metabolic models.

title: Role of Databases in Metabolic Reconstruction
content: Key databases such as KEGG, MetaCyc, BiGG Models, and BRENDA provide curated information on reactions, enzymes, pathways, and metabolites essential for accurate model reconstruction.

title: Applications of Metabolic Models
content: Genome-scale metabolic models are used in metabolic engineering, drug target identification, microbiome analysis, evolutionary studies, and personalized medicine to predict phenotypic behavior under genetic or environmental perturbations.
